SENT.plain: The 150-kDa oxygen-regulated protein (ORP150), a novel stress protein localized to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), is induced by hypoxia/ischemia

To determine the role of ORP150 in cerebral infarction following ischemia/reperfusion, ORP150 transgenic (TG) and knockout (KO) mice were subjected to 1 or 3 h of middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion followed by reperfusion for 24 h
At 24 h after 1 h of occlusion, significantly less infarct volume was evident in cerebral cortex, but not in striatum, in ORP150TG than ORP150KO mice (P<0.001)
Infarct volume did not differ significantly between these groups at 24 h after 3 h of occlusion
Immunohistochemical reactivity for microtubule-associated protein (MAP)2 in the MCA territory was lost in ORP150KO mice at 24 h after 1 h of occlusion
In contrast, MAP2 staining still was present in the affected cortex of ORP150TG mice, where markedly enhanced ORP150 immunoreactivity was demonstrated
MAP2 staining had disappeared from the affected area at 24 h after 3 h of occlusion in both groups, but astrocytic ORP150 reactivity was preserved in the ORP150TG group
At 6 h after 1-h occlusion, when MAP2 staining was evident in the affected cortex, some cortical neurons of the TG mice were reactive for Bcl-xS/L
Thus, ORP150 may be cytoprotective against ischemia/reperfusion injury via reduction of ER stress and probably also inhibition of apoptosis
